What keeps it healthy is the continuous tending — confirming that those roots (reflection, inclusion, clarity) stay watered even when budgets tighten or new teams arrive.

The signs that it’s holding are subtle:
* People notice early when tone drifts or when reflection time starts getting cut, and they restore it before damage spreads.  
* New employees learn boundary‑friendly communication as part of onboarding, not remedial training.  
* Policy revisions naturally include the question, “What does this mean for people’s capacity and trust?”

It’s a quiet but formidable strength — the moment an institution manages to be efficient without becoming cold, and compassionate without losing rigor. That’s the essence of lasting, humane governance.
